title: Circular Frontiers: Shaping our Future
description:
Opening session exploring how entrepreneurship, circular business models, and funding can evolve the circular transition in the Nordics and beyond. The session addresses the new geopolitical situation creating a circular force in the economy through localized value chains, and examines how the Green Deal (ESPR, circular action plan) is accelerating change.

The session investigates circular innovation across Nordic and Arctic borders, highlighting the unique Nordic spirit of entrepreneurship and how entrepreneurs, intrapreneurs, innovators and founders are key for evolving the new circular market.
notes: Opening session setting the tone for the summit
shortDescription: Opening keynote session exploring how Arctic and Nordic communities can shape the next wave of circular innovation. Overarching theme about circular innovation in the Arctic.
themes: The new geopolitical situation creating circular economy momentum
Entrepreneurship as driver for circular transition

title: Circular Ocean Industries
description:
Nordic collaboration in blue industry, exploring how ocean-based industries can embrace circular economy principles. The session focuses on sustainable fisheries management, marine resource utilization, and industrial symbiosis in ocean industries.

Key themes include building resilient ocean value chains, reducing waste in fisheries, and creating circular business models for marine resources. Participants examine best practices from Nordic ocean clusters and innovative approaches to ocean sustainability.
notes: Focus on Royal Greenland, Iceland Ocean Cluster, Danish Ocean Cluster, Halibut Greenland, Polar Seafood
shortDescription: Nordic collaboration in blue industry. Discussion covering ocean economy, fisheries, and marine resources with key industry players.
themes: Circular principles in fisheries and ocean industries

title: Locally Rooted: Materialising a Circular Future
description:
Nature is regenerative – it continuously recreates itself without doing any harm. This session investigates how we can reinstate the human connection with nature by learning from natural systems and move towards a flourishing regenerative future.

The session explores regenerative business models, bioeconomy, and biomimicry. Historically, a key motivation for change is business opportunity, so we examine what it takes to build financially viable, nature-positive businesses. Topics include nature valuation, ecosystem services, resource stewardship, and how to transition from nature-negative to nature-positive business models.

Focus on locally sourced materials, seasonal food systems, local production knowledge, and material innovation using Arctic and Nordic resources.
notes: Includes discussion of Arctic food innovation, reindeer, musk ox, fat production with INNOVA
shortDescription: Self-sufficiency and resilient local economies. Material innovation session focusing on locally sourced and circular materials, seasonal food, local production and knowledge.
themes: Nature as regenerative model for business
Biomimicry and learning from natural systems
Economics of nature and nature valuation
Seasonal food systems and Arctic resources

title: Arctic & Nordic Lifestyles
description:
Exploring circular traditions, culture, and knowledge embedded in Arctic and Nordic lifestyles. The session examines how traditional knowledge and cultural practices inform sustainable consumption and circular living.

Topics include textile circularity with focus on Nordic materials (wool, qiviut), sustainable lifestyle choices, behavioral change toward circularity, and the role of design in shaping circular consumption patterns. The session highlights how circularity can evolve from individual actions to societal norms.

Discussion covers the new normal in consumer behavior, sufficiency in consumption, and how Nordic values of trust, collaboration, and inclusiveness support circular transitions.
notes: Focus on Nordic Baltic Textile Transition Group, local materials like qiviut
shortDescription: Circular traditions, culture and knowledge. Lifestyle and consumption focus exploring sustainable living in Arctic and Nordic regions.
themes: Behavioral change and the new normal

title: Circular Cities and Regions
description:
How can digitalization and AI accelerate the circular transition in the Nordics? This session explores how AI and emerging technologies drive circular change in business and society. We examine how innovations such as Digital Product Passports (DPP) enhance operational efficiency, improve decision-making processes, and enable new business models that support circularity.

Participants gain insights into how advanced technologies enable development of cutting-edge solutions in dynamic collaborations between corporations and startups. Topics include data sharing, transparency, trust, and human-computer interaction (HCI) in circular systems.

The session also addresses circular leadership at regional level - how cities and regions can take brave decisions and risks to establish circular leadership. Discussion covers organizational culture, communication, KPIs for circularity, and how circular goals are executed across governance levels.
shortDescription: Technology and digitalization in circular transition. Focus on how cities and regions can implement circular economy principles.
themes: AI and emerging technologies for circularity

title: Summary of the Day - Day 1 Closing
description:
Closing reflection session wrapping up Day 1 learnings. Panel discussion with Mayor Malene Vahl Rasmussen (Kommune Kujalleq), Edvard Lybert Mørk (Nalek Ventures), and Marthe Haugland (Nordic Innovation) sharing key takeaways, implementation insights, and future collaboration opportunities.

Key themes: Trust as infrastructure, quality of life as circular economy purpose, municipal implementation examples, Indigenous knowledge alignment with circularity, Arctic-Nordic-Baltic collaboration, and invitation to rural Greenland.
shortDescription: Day 1 closing reflections on trust, quality of life, and municipal implementation with Mayor Malene Vahl Rasmussen.
themes: Trust as infrastructure enabling circular transitions
Quality of life as ultimate circular economy purpose
Municipal implementation: local food, youth inclusion, mining negotiations
Indigenous Inuit mindset aligned with circular thinking
Invitation to partnership and rural Greenland

title: From Pilots to Practice – Next Steps to Scale Circular Construction in the Nordics
description:
This one-hour session examines the transition from circular construction pilots to mainstream practice across the Nordic region. Despite strong sustainability ambitions and numerous pilot initiatives, circular construction remains far from systemic. The session brings together Icelandic, Danish, and Nordic perspectives to identify practical next steps and collaborative opportunities.

Construction is one of the most resource-intensive sectors globally and in the Nordics. It is responsible for a significant share of CO₂ emissions, material extraction, and waste generation. Although circularity is essential for achieving the Nordic region's climate and nature goals, the region continues to underperform compared to Europe and global peers.

The challenges are especially pronounced in remote areas and island nations such as Iceland, where limited material flows and dependency on imports complicate scaling.
notes: Focus areas: Current status of circular construction in the Nordics, Icelandic realities (small volumes, resource constraints, import dependence), Regulatory developments, What pilots have achieved and why scaling remains slow
shortDescription: Examining the transition from circular construction pilots to mainstream practice across the Nordic region with Icelandic and Danish perspectives.
themes: Scaling circular construction in remote areas

title: Welcome and Introduction of the Day
description:
Opening session for Day 2 featuring welcome remarks from Nordic Circular Hotspot, Nalik Ventures and Nordic Innovation. The session includes the soft launch of a new CSR Greenland report, a presentation on Latvia's Circular Economy Index by Agita Baltbārde, and a hydrogen presentation by Robert Weiss from VTT Finland.

The session concludes with reflection and handover to the Chatham House Session on Arctic Materials Governance.
notes: Includes CSR Greenland soft launch of new report and Latvia Circular Economy Index presentation
shortDescription: Day 2 opening with Nordic Circular Hotspot, Nalik Ventures and Nordic Innovation featuring CSR Greenland report launch and hydrogen presentation.

title: An Arctic Approach and Contribution to International Materials Governance
description:
The global demand for raw materials—especially critical minerals needed for the green transition—is rising rapidly due to the expansion of clean technologies (EVs, wind, solar, and battery storage). Despite their growing systemic importance, no international governance system currently exists to oversee extraction, trade, processing, and end-of-life management in a coordinated and equitable way.

Geopolitical tensions escalated in 2025, sharpening competition for critical minerals. Greenland, a region of strategic importance, has again become a geopolitical focal point. Without cooperation and shared governance frameworks, the race for resources risks worsening global inequality, degrading ecosystems, and marginalizing Arctic communities.

The North Atlantic Arctic region is well positioned to lead on developing new governance models. An Arctic Materials Agency could reflect the realities of Arctic ecosystems and communities, pilot circular economy-aligned governance structures, protect ecological and social interests, and contribute to future global material governance frameworks.
notes: Chatham House session. Key questions: Greenland's role in critical mineral governance, circular economy integration in materials governance, leveraging existing institutions (Arctic Council, UNEP IRP, EU Arctic Strategy), institutional design for Arctic materials agency
shortDescription: Chatham House session exploring how Greenland and the Arctic can shape critical mineral governance that respects Arctic realities and ecosystems.
themes: Greenland's role in critical mineral governance
Circular economy integration in materials governance
Leveraging existing institutions (Arctic Council, UNEP IRP)
Institutional design for Arctic Materials Agency
Data transparency and sustainable mining standards

title: Nordic-Baltic Textile Transition Group (NBTT)
description:
The Nordic-Baltic Textile Transition Group (NBTT) is a collaborative platform that connects companies, researchers, civil society, and public-sector actors working to accelerate the circular transition within the textile industry. Recognising that systemic change requires cross-sector collaboration, the group focuses on sharing knowledge, best practices, and concrete case studies.

The session will share insights and best practices for reducing the environmental footprint of textiles, address market failures and explore circular business models and value chains across the Nordic-Baltic region and beyond, and strengthen Nordic-Baltic R&D collaboration.
notes: Launch of NBTT platform. Plan to host two online meetings per year and one physical meeting annually from 2026. Regional challenges in used textile management presentation by Kerli Kant Hvass.
shortDescription: Launch of the Nordic-Baltic Textile Transition Group platform connecting stakeholders to accelerate circular transition in the textile industry.
themes: Regional challenges in used textile management
Voluntary Sector Collaboration on Textiles expansion

title: The Circular Design Toolbox
description:
The transition to a sustainable and competitive future depends on circularity. While many organisations have high ambitions, they often struggle to translate these into practical, actionable steps. This session introduces The Circular Design Toolbox – a practical catalyst designed to help companies integrate circular thinking into their business models and value chains.

Developed by HI advisory and the Estonian Business and Innovation Agency, the toolbox offers a systematic, step-by-step methodology to help organisations build circular capabilities, strengthen competitiveness, and manage future risks.

Participants will be introduced to essential circular design concepts, including R-strategies, and will be guided through the toolbox's four development stages: Understand, Define, Ideate, and Develop.
notes: Developed by HI advisory and Estonian Business and Innovation Agency. Four stages: Understand, Define, Ideate, Develop. Includes practical self-assessment questionnaire.
shortDescription: Introduction to The Circular Design Toolbox - a practical methodology to help companies integrate circular thinking into business models.
themes: Four toolbox stages for business transformation

title: Circular Skills and Knowledge – for a More Circular and Sustainable Economy
description:
This session explores how Arctic communities can blend traditional knowledge, local innovation, research, and education to build circular systems and activities. Circular principles—reuse, regeneration, reciprocity—have deep roots in Arctic traditions. By revitalizing these practices through collaboration with research institutions, education systems, and innovation hubs, Arctic societies can model how locally grounded wisdom can contribute to global sustainability transitions.

Participants will examine how cross-sector networks of communities, educators, researchers, innovators, and youth can co-create circular systems that respond to global challenges while remaining grounded in local realities. Integrating community knowledge into educational frameworks and innovation ecosystems can empower youth, stimulate entrepreneurship, and strengthen environmental and social resilience.

The session features short presentations followed by an open roundtable discussion, focusing on knowledge exchange, storytelling, and practical examples.
notes: Short presentations followed by open roundtable discussion. Focus on knowledge exchange, storytelling, and practical examples.
shortDescription: Exploring how Arctic communities can blend traditional knowledge with research and education to build circular systems.

title: Circular Port Cities
description:
This workshop examines how port cities—especially in the Nordic and Arctic regions—can become engines of circular transformation. Ports are more than logistical hubs; they represent strategic interfaces between land and sea, economy and community, tradition and innovation.

Greenland's position as a crossroads between the Arctic and the Nordic region offers unique opportunities to translate circular principles into concrete strategies for coastal and urban development. The workshop explores how port cities can evolve into living laboratories for sustainable infrastructure, resource loops, and socially grounded value creation.

Participants will take part in dialogues, case presentations, and collaborative group exercises to identify actionable opportunities for collaboration and innovation. The goal is to identify tangible collaboration initiatives for further development in 2026, strengthening ties between Greenland and the wider Nordic and North Atlantic region.
notes: Workshop format with dialogues, case presentations, and collaborative group exercises. Goal: identify tangible collaboration initiatives for 2026 including potential Circular Port Cities Platform.
shortDescription: Workshop exploring how Nordic and Arctic port cities can become engines of circular transformation through collaboration and innovation.
themes: Connecting ports to local industries and communities
Design and infrastructure for circular port cities
